name: Michigan Advance
title: Poor air quality hinders Detroit veterans’ access to green space, Sierra Club finds
description: As health researchers point to a number of physical and health positives brought on by exposure to nature, a new report from the Sierra Club finds that more than 20% of Detroit military veterans are unable to access those benefits.  While 58% of military veterans treated between 2002 and 2015 had a diagnosed mental health […]
text:
Photo credit: Kyle Grillot, Sierra ClubAs health researchers point to a number of physical and health positives brought on by exposure to nature, a new report from the Sierra Club finds that more than 20% of Detroit military veterans are unable to access those benefits. 
While 58% of military veterans treated between 2002 and 2015 had a diagnosed mental health disorder, less than half of U.S. vets seek out treatment due to the cost, lack of availability and stigma. In response, mental health professionals, veterans groups and researchers have sought alternatives to in-office treatment, finding positive results with outdoor recreation and exposure. 
Although adventure-based trips like backpacking and whitewater rafting had a positive impact on veterans facing PTSD, anxiety, depression and other conditions, the Sierra Club report notes these programs are only available sporadically. Additionally, many areas lack the natural resources needed for this recreational therapy. 
Detroit received a “D” for veteran access to nearby nature in the Sierra Club’s “Roots of Resilience” report. Credit: Heather Stricker / Sierra Club
Veterans need access to quality natural spaces near their homes, the report says, emphasizing that this space should be accessible  regardless of transportation availability, connection to organized outings, or their personal economic situations.
Air pollution can also complicate access to green spaces, as many veterans suffer from respiratory and cardiovascular conditions, making them more sensitive to pollutants, preventing them from engaging in outdoor activities. 
The report examined eight cities across the U.S., including Detroit, assessing each based on the amount of vets lacking access to nature, as well as the American Lung Association’s 2025 state of the air grades. 
In its assessment of Detroit, the report notes that its park system is growing, as it encompasses nearly 5,000 acres across 300 parks. While 84% of residents live within a 10-minute walk of a park, 20% of veterans lacked access to nature in their neighborhoods, with the Sierra Club rating the city a “B” for overall nature access.
However, the city’s “F” rating from the American Lung Association, low walkability and poor access to public transit, pose a barrier to veterans’ park access, the report notes.
Additionally, the neighborhoods with the highest concentrations of people of color also had access to 38% less park space than the neighborhoods with the most white residents. Taking all of these factors into consideration, the report gave Detroit a “D” rating overall. 
A table from the Sierra Club’s veterans access to nature report card examining nature access, walkability and air quality in eight U.S. cities. | Sierra Club
With many veterans facing long-term respiratory, cardiovascular and mental health conditions that can be made worse by pollution, the Sierra Club emphasized the importance of maintaining protections for clean air, water and for public lands, to support nature-based therapy and limit further exposure of veterans to toxic air pollution.
“When parks are closed, air is polluted, or communities near bases suffer environmental damage, veterans—many of whom live in those areas—bear the brunt,” the report states. “Protecting the environment is not just an ecological responsibility; it’s part of the nation’s duty of care to those who served.”
The report also recommends supporting efforts to connect veterans with nature, supporting staffing and funding for public lands, and improving accessible infrastructure in parks and public land.
